heading: journey to the interior, exterior
subheading: nasa has plans to get to know the sun's closest neighbor and a certain comet headed our way. the missions will provide the closest look yet at the outside of fiery mercury and the first-ever look inside a comet. by lindsey arent.
author: lindsey arent
text: in an effort to better understand our solar neighborhood, nasa has two new scientific missions: the first, to map mercury in detail, and another to try to discover what lies at a comet's core. "the whole purpose is to select missions that will give us fundamental advancements in our understanding of the solar system," said jay bergstralh, a discovery program scientist at nasa.the messenger project -- formally known as the mercury surface, space environment geochemistry and ranging mission -- will send seven different mapping and measuring instruments into orbit around the smallest planet in the solar system.meanwhile, the appropriately titled deep impact mission, will launch a giant copper projectile deep into the center of comet p/temple 1, allowing scientists to study the pristine inner material thought be unchanged since the formation of the solar system.messenger, which is slated for a spring 2004 launch, will be nasa's first mission to mercury in nearly 30 years. the mariner 10 missions in 1974 and 1975 only provided information on half the planet.this time, instruments will take a year studying the entire planet -- its shape, magnetic field, and interior composition -- and will transmit the first global images of mercury back to earth. scientists also hope to discover whether mercury has water ice in its polar craters."we want to know how mercury evolved, what its interior structure is," bergstralh said. "mercury is a small planet, but it's very dense, and it has a permanent magnetic field that is a big mystery for a body as small as that."the journey won't be easy. "it�s hard to get there and it's a hostile environment, very hot."the mission is expected to cost nasa us$286 million. the instruments will be built by the applied physics laboratory at johns hopkins university.the deep impact project is likely to be a more glamorous mission. with its 1,100-pound copper harpoon traveling at around 10 kilometers per second, nasa scientists hope to create an crater as big as a football field and as deep as a seven-story building in the nucleus of the comet. the kinetic energy of that impact will equal six tons of tnt, officials said.the spacecraft will carry cameras and an infrared spectrometer that will analyze the materials blasted off the comet during the impact."we think that comets are made of the primordial stuff that the solar system is made of," bergstralh said. "they're like chemical fossils and we want to find out what its interior is made of."large observatories on earth in hawaii and chile will also observe the impact. and assuming all goes as predicted, amateur astronomers also will be able to see the impact on the very loaded date of 4 july 2005. the blast will cost nasa a tidy $240 million.both the messenger and deep impact missions were chosen as part of nasa's discovery program, which aims to find low-cost answers to perplexing planetary questions.discovery programs, such as the mars pathfinder probe, involve collaborations with university scientists, government labs, and aerospace contractors. the projects must be ready for launch no later than 30 september 2004, and price tags must not exceed $299 million.
